segments.text: This is Debra Beale and I am interviewing Dr. Richard Thomas on the history of the Texas Engineering Experiment Station.
The date is June 15th, 1984.
...section on here already, so tell us who you are.
I'd like to put some background on your education and how you came down here.
Well, I wouldn't say how far back in it.
You talked about university education in Richmond.
I did all my work up at Ohio State, finished, or left there rather, in 64.
My background is basically aerospace engineering, that's where my PhD is,
but also studied mathematics and math too.
But I was brought into the Department of Aerospace Engineering here back in 1964.
You were gone for a few years, right?
Yeah, I made the mistake of leaving Texas A&M at one time.
I was offered a job as a department head at Maryland and left and went up there.
My family and I discovered that some hard-bitten old Midwestern conservatives
didn't fit well into the heartland of the liberal eastern establishment.
And... And it was really principally Washington.
It wasn't the University of Maryland.
I enjoyed the university and had a great time there.
But it was just the general mood and environment of Washington, D.C. itself that we didn't fit into.
And so after we were there a couple of years, I determined that I had made a mistake
and taken the family there and decided to go elsewhere.
And I actually was pursuing some jobs in some other areas.
And I thought, well, I would contact Fred Benson, who was dean here.
And he was kind enough to offer me an opportunity to come back to Texas A&M.
And so we did come back then in the early 70s.
That was a right move, incidentally.
When you first came here, what type of research was going on?
Well, that's a very relevant question regarding the history and general impact of TEAS.
Because within the Aero Department, there wasn't any research going on.
Mr. Rutter was our president then.
He recognized that research was key to the image of an institution that aspired to greatness.
But any of the so-called...
Great universities, their reputation is built more on their research than on their academic programs.
In my view, the undergraduate program at MIT, for example, is rather pedestrian.
And I just assumed if I had a student who wanted to study...
A son who wanted to study aerospace engineering, I'd just...
Frankly, I'd rather have him here than MIT.
And when you get into graduate work, that's something else again.
It's a different story.
But it is research that...
That makes the image of an institution.
I once heard that Mr. Rutter had said, I don't know whether it's true or not,
that he was going to make Texas A&M the MIT of the Southwest,
or I guess that would also mean possibly make MIT the Texas A&M of the Northeast or something,
although they'd have to go a bit to do that.
But it was clear that when I was hired here in 64,
they didn't ask whether I could teach or not.
They were interested in the fact that I had been involved in a very active research program,
and above all, I knew how to hustle money
and convince sponsors that they ought to give me money for research.
There wasn't any...
It was... That's what I was supposed to do.
Because, as I say, when I came into the aerial department,
as I recall, there was not anyone at that time.
Now, they had had some off and on,
but there wasn't any...
There wasn't any large, consistent program.
You did mostly aeronautical research versus aerospace, too.
Well, it wasn't even...
No, I don't make any distinction there.
Oh, okay.
Yeah.
Now, shortly after I came here, there was another group within AERO
and coupled with ME that had a piece of research dealing with propeller thrust studies.
And I'm sure they would have gotten that, had...
That was the directive that was given to me.
And...
But did it change much between the time you came and...
No.
No.
It hasn't changed all that much today.
Now, the structure has changed a bit.
It was what it is now and what it was then.
And this gets into some of the personnel changes that were in since 64.
I cannot...
I cannot overemphasize the importance of TEA.
In that whole process.
And as a matter of fact, the importance of TEA's in my decision to come to Texas A&M.
And if you want to get into that now, we can.
But it wasn't absolutely critical.
Because quite frankly, I think if there hadn't been TEA's, I wouldn't have come to Texas A&M.
It's that simple.
And I well remember what a very positive reaction that I had after my interview.
Because I thought,
these people know how it's done.
And the positive reaction came largely from two men.
Al Kronk, who was then the head of the Aerospace Department.
And above all, Harry Whitmore.
Who had just come in, I think, in what, 63, I think?
Just a year before to head up the Space Technology Division, so-called.
Now, I'm going to say some...
Make some comments here that would appear to be critical of Al Kronk.
But they should not be interpreted that way.
He was, and still is, although he's in poor health now, a hell of a guy.
And I really came to love that man.
However, Al was like so many of our engineering department heads back in those days.
In that he was not research-oriented.
He did not promote research.
He did not push faculty to do research.
Texas A&M's image back in the 50s, I think, although it's not here.
But I think it was one of the super undergraduate educational institutions.
And in the engineering, it turned out people that were very well equipped to go into industry.
And do the job.
But as I say, when Mr. Rutter came aboard in about 58, I guess, as chancellor, I think, or president.
I'm not really sure how that all happened.
But he was the one who really started to promote research activities at Texas A&M.
Well, we had, as I say, we had a number of engineering department heads.
Cliff Semang in mechanical engineering.
Bob Whiting in petroleum engineering.
And on and on.
Burgess in industrial engineering.
Great guys.
Super teachers.
Super educators.
But researchers, quite honestly, it was always my perception.
Nobody ever told me this.
But it was always my perception that the space technology division and Mr. Whitmore were set up.
To, well, one might say to go around Al Kronk.
And I suppose, you know, that wouldn't be too far off base.
But really it was more to supplement what was Kronk, what Professor Kronk was doing in the educational arena.
And get a very definite research thrust going.
To me, when I came down here in the spring of 64, TEAS had money to spend in the promotion of research.
And above all, they knew what that meant.
This had just a tremendous impact on it.
Because I was, I had determined, although I looked at industry when I decided to leave Ohio State.
I had determined I was going to stay in the academic world.
I went over, well, among the institutions that I interviewed was Georgia Tech.
And they had a pretty good research program.
But I was absolutely turned off by their attitude.
They wanted me to promote research.
They wanted me to hustle money.
And I said to them, well, do you have money to travel, you know, to go visit research funds?
And they said, well, you can take that out of your research money.
I said, wait a minute.
You can't, you know, you're asking me to pull myself up by my boot straps.
You've got to prime the pump a bit here, you know.
And it was clear they weren't all that willing to do that.
But Mr. Whitmore and TEAS.
Were willing.
And he understood.
And keep in mind, of course, not a lot of that credit goes to Fred Benson.
Because he understands, too, what is involved in building a program.
And it's something that you just don't do overnight.
So they understood that in the promotion of research, one does not sit down and write out a proposal.
However technically excellent it might be.
And send it to the sponsor, the potential sponsor.
And say, send money by return made.
It just does not happen that way.
You must go there.
You must sell yourself.
You have to hustle.
And that, to some, is sort of the senior side of academia.
But you've got to do it.
And there's just no substitute for having support of that type.
And I think that, and having the Research Foundation.
Of course, it was a great thing.
Of course, it was a great asset, too.
Because there you could get a professional-looking proposal turned out.
Obviously, they, coupled with TEAS, would help you manage your project, your money, once you got it.
And that's essential.
Because when I went, again, just to illustrate.
When I went to the University of Maryland.
Again, I went into a department, if you can believe this, 20 minutes from downtown Washington.
Where many of the research sponsors were located.
And again, when I went to Maryland, that department had not paid anyone a research.
And they did not have a research foundation.
They did not have a research foundation.
And I lucked out and rather quickly got a nice grant from NASA to do some wind tunnel studies.
And I had to hire a gal into the department office there to keep books on this project.
You know, the very sorts of things that the Research Foundation and TEAS do for you.
Well, that kind of support, you see, is just inestimable value in the promotion of research.
And so all of that infrastructure was here.
And of course, Ohio State had had a very strong research foundation.
Their engineering experiment station was nothing like this.
So I had some appreciation of what these support institutions could do for you.
And that was all here.
And that was all in place.
And to have that, you see, coupled with Mr. Whitmore's attitude.
You know, yeah, I got some money for you.
You need help.
You come see me.
And it was just too good to pass up.
Of course, you know, I'd have to say that there were some other factors.
And I liked the attitude of the people.
But in terms of Dick Thomas' professional development, I don't think I could have found,
and frankly, I tell young people today, I don't think they could find today any better atmosphere.
Although the teaching loans, of course, have increased substantially in recent years.
And that's, I know, a very negative factor in recruiting people.
But in terms of promoting research, it's difficult to find a better atmosphere.
They have to find a better environment, a better atmosphere in which to do that.
So T's contributed heavily, I think, to the elevation of Texas A&M's image as a research institution.
We've still got a ways to go.
But when you look, when you consider about 26 years since Mr. Rutter took over and set us on this path,
if you look back at what we've accomplished in those 25 years, it's really quite incredible.
It really is.
A lot of people don't appreciate that.
But T's contributed heavily to that.
When you first came, was the wind tunnel still housing hay?
Was it still what?
Was it still a hay barn?
Well, not quite.
Almost.
They know where to start.
My, that brings back a lot of memories.
The wind tunnel was there and had recently, that is, I say recently, but I think, I'm not sure when it was,
I think in the late 50s and early 60s, had been upgraded.
Because initially it was an open circuit or an open throat type wind tunnel.
And that, you just have difficulty doing precise research in a facility like that.
And so they had put in the, they had closed it, they had put in the return leg.
And Joe Bruce and his crew had a magnificent job of ferreting out sources of turbulence and instability in the tunnel.
And they had put in the balance to measure forces on models.
And, but it had kind of fallen on hard times because I think, although they had put in the balance,
they did not put in a data system.
A system that would more or less automatically, excuse me, automatically process the data coming out of the balance and out of the wind tunnel.
And I don't know whether that was, well, there was another problem too.
I should back up here a bit and say, as you've probably already been told,
it was hoped that by upgrading the tunnel could do, it could support itself with commercial testing
for like LTD and general dynamics and others.
And it also, of course, it would provide a basis for some good aerodynamic research.
Well, at about that time, for whatever reason, building its own wind tunnel facilities and other organizations did too.
And I think that, coupled with the fact that we weren't really wind tunnel data,
it just led to the circumstance that occurred when I came in,
and that was that the wind tunnel had been shut down basically.
We were just sitting there gathering dust.
And so, to that extent, it was, I think, I remember one of the first groups of students that I had.
The first courses I taught dealt with low-speed aerodynamics.
And so, I went across and used the wind tunnel for some student demonstrations.
And so, I took a bunch of students out there, and down in the basement of the tunnel,
we found a big box that looked rather like a coffin.
But in that box, we found a model, a wind tunnel model.
And it had been, it was a, that's the T in LinkedIn and LTV.
Temco, back, I don't know, back in the 50s,
was preparing a bid on,
on the development and production of a cargo airplane for the Air Force or something.
And they had this, this model.
And apparently, they were unsuccessful in their bid.
And, and of course, were then, were then absorbed by,
and apparently never took the model back.
And so, the traditional Aggie enthusiasm,
my students tore into that thing.
They assembled the model.
We installed it in the wind tunnel with Mr. Bruce's invaluable assistance.
And we ran a series of tests on that model.
And again, this was just principally for the educational.
But we sort of blew the dust out of the tunnel at that time.
And, and I guess it was through that experience that I,
I became convinced that it was a fine facility.
It had excellent flow characteristics.
And I thought it, you know, I thought it was possible to,
to do some research.
And although that, it was out of my area.
I mean, I was trained principally in hypersonic aerodynamics and not in M number.
But I learned to fly during World War II.
And I still enjoy flying.
And so, you know, to that extent, I'm interested.
Because the airplanes I fly, they'll go.
And, and I, we were fortunate then in the,
in the mid-60s to,
to get some work for NASA, from NASA,
for work in the wind tunnel.
But here again, you see, this,
I, I well remember a trip that I took to NASA Langley
after having done what groundwork I could do by phone.
And I went up there and talked to a guy who eventually became a very good friend,
Jerry Rainey.
And, and essentially convinced him that he ought to give some money to Texas A&M.
And, and you see, if, if, if I'd been at Georgia Tech, for example,
or some other institution that didn't have that,
that support for you, it would have just been impossible.
And, and there was another element to that, incidentally.
Thinking back on it, the aero department has a small wind tunnel,
a two foot by three foot, I think it is.
Yeah, I've seen that.
That's not anywhere near the same wind tunnel.
Right.
Okay.
We, we were doing some work on dust genera,
we were proposing for Langley to do some work on dust generations.
And, and we built a little prototype of our dust generator
and put it in that tunnel, in that small tunnel to prove the concept.
And, and that, that construction of that little prototype was done with key's money.
And I'm sure that when I went to see Mr. Rainey at Langley,
and, and I showed him, I said, you know,
we did a, we did a little very crude improvisation of,
of what we wanted to do in the big tunnel.
And he was impressed with that.
And so here, this is just the way, just the way T's,
the T's work, you see, the T's money works.
Just absolutely invaluable.
When you came back in 71, did, did you become involved in the shuttle research?
In what?
Shuttle research?
No, no.
What were you doing?
When I, you see, in 1970 or, well, 69,
when, when Neil Armstrong set foot on the moon,
the space program started downhill.
And also, for the first time in history,
all three of the support areas generally active in aerospace engineering went downhill.
That is, aerospace engineering,
in the 60s and so forth, 70s, rested on a three-legged stool.
One is commercial and general aviation.
Another one is military aviation and the third is space.
And generally, in times past, those things would not be synchronized.
That is, if one went down, one of the other would be going up,
and things were relatively bad.
In the late 60s and early 70s,
for the first time in history, they all three went down together.
It was not a good time for, for an aerospace engineer to be out looking for a job.
Research money had dried up.
The student enrollments went down in the early 70s
because engineers couldn't get jobs, you know.
The department over here had, had more faculty than it needed.
Norton and others will tell you.
Jim Strickland, when he was in the lot, they,
they were urged to go out and hustle and research money
in order to keep themselves afloat financially.
Because they just, I think in, by 1973 or 4,
I think the total number of graduates out of the department
was something like 20.
It had dried up incredibly.
And so, when I came back,
Mr. Benson put me in a position as a, as a special assistant to him
with the task of
simply promoting some new research for the 14s
and for the College of Engineering.
And, and I did not, as a matter of fact, my title at that time was,
my academic title was professor of engineering,
professor of aerospace engineering.
And so it was only later on when the enrollments came back
that I got a so, no, not anything to do test.
Prior to those tests, we did get the
wind tunnel back in operation and,
and we had a going facility.
And then, of course, NASA came in and bought us a data system,
bought us a computer to do the, the processing.
And that's the kind of a facility we should have had back in the,
in the early 60s.
Did they have those types of things developed in the early 60s?
Yeah, they weren't, they were mostly analog computers.
They were not, but yeah, they had, they had facilities that made it.
And that was the big problem.
You see, when a guy runs a wind tunnel test,
he wants the results right now.
Because, of course, oftentimes the look at the data,
the way that looks and his interpretation of that,
that will determine what the next test is going to be.
Well, you see the, the setup they had in the late 50s
and early 60s was such that they could take data in a very raw form
and they had to bring it in to the DPC.
Punch it into CARMS and then process it the next day,
you know, the sponsored movie.
When you came back as the assistant,
were other departments besides aerospace having,
were other departments having trouble getting research money too?
Was there a slope in any of the others?
Oh, no, dear, I don't, I don't think I'd say that.
Incidentally, we're skipping over some other,
some other things here that occurred in the late 60s
that, that would involve TEAS,
and I guess we ought to come back and talk about those.
Because, you see, we haven't talked about the flight lab,
we haven't talked about the shock tube,
both of which resulted totally from what TEAS did.
But to answer your question,
no, there, in the, in the 60s and 70s,
there was a general push toward the hiring of faculty
that had research capability.
And so just as I had been hired in,
I had been hired into Aero to,
and had been successful in hiring other people in other departments.
And so I think Texas A&M was moving on a fairly broad front in research.
Now, these were mainly in what you might call the traditional.
And so when I came back,
I had a conversation, or before I came back,
I had a conversation with,
with a conversation I will never forget.
And he, and incidentally, I was not an assistant dean.
I was a special assistant to the dean.
And so, and it was, and it was purely a research.
It had no academic, and I didn't work with,
but Mr. Benson, a lot of people think that he's a staid outreach,
because, and here again, this was,
this was a kind of a typical TEAS operation.
He, he just simply wanted me to find some new areas
in which, in which TEAS and the College of Engineering could work,
non-traditional areas.
And as far as he was concerned,
I had carte blanche to move in any direction I wanted.
It was as if he had given me a little chunk of money,
which he did, and said, in effect,
here, go do something great with this.
And it was absolutely one of the most exhilarating experiences I ever had in my life.
He, and he just, he just ran some things by me, you know,
the way he was thinking.
He said that he thought that,
of course, keep in mind we were,
we were in the midst of the Vietnam debacle at that time.
He said, you know, for the first time in history,
our technology has failed us.
But he suggested that,
that we might do a piece of research looking at why technology failed,
or if technology had, and if it had, why it had.
That, and I, I nosed into it a little bit to find out that,
at that point, there was so much stonewalling going on.
Of course, you had, you'd have to have access to classified data.
So we didn't pursue that.
He was very concerned about advanced transportation systems.
And that kind of surprised me, because, of course,
he had been the founder of TTIP.
But he was concerned that TTI was not reaching out far enough,
and they were too content to sit here doing
highway research.
I mean, good stuff, don't misunderstand.
Good stuff, but,
but research that was, again, pretty traditional stuff.
And at that time, there was great interest in some of these
people-mover systems and
old things like the Air Trans up at Dallas,
the DFW airport, you know, unmanned, automated kinds of systems.
And he thought we ought to be getting into that.
And so we,
we did mount some efforts in that.
The whole issue of productivity and to use new technology
to increase the efficiency of manufacturing and production
was still, of course, very, very hot to Mr. Benson,
but that he saw that coming down the road.
So, as I say, he just wanted me to sort of follow my nose
and try to develop some new research areas for the,
that was my assignment when I came here.
You said productivity developed into being here.
What group was it that was doing this?
Well, there wasn't any group doing it at the time.
And so the,
well, the people that we drew on to folks out of industrial engineering
were some other folks in M.E.
and W.E.
that put the involvement principle came out of industrial engineering.
But the thrust of that, as it turned out,
was, well, I guess there were, there were two things.
One major thrust dealt with technology transfer.
That has a different connotation today than it did then.
Those words nowadays, when you say technology transfer,
generally talk, people are talking about the movement of technology
from the U.S. to the Soviet Union, and a vital question.
But back in those days, it had to do with what might better be called
the diffusion of technology.
That is to say, one of the things we studied
dealt with numerically controlled machines.
These are machine tools, lathes, milling machines, and so forth,
that early on were controlled by what you might call a very crude computer.
It was a numerical system, an automated system,
really based on punched paper tapes,
paper tape with holes in it that contained signals
that would guide the machine.
And so instead of having a machinist sit there with his eye,
you know, twisting the knobs very carefully and so forth,
it was all automated.
If you went up to General Dynamics, for example,
and bought an aerospace manufacturer's, for example,
you'd find lots of NC machines.
You'd go to Hughes Tool or Cameron Ironworks
or some of the smaller machine shops that populate Hughes,
which indicated that, for some reason,
or other, that technology had not diffused,
had not moved through American industry.
And the belief was, quite properly, that if we could do that,
if we could somehow stimulate that,
that we could help industry increase its productivity,
become more efficient, become more competitive with Japan and Germany.
So that was the general idea.
It headed much toward the...
Was there a particular center?
No, no.
It never evolved into that.
We just simply called it the Productivity Program.
And we had a problem emerge there,
quite honestly, that we still have today.
And this is, I guess, here I'm going,
I'm about to utter my first critical remark of T's.
The kinds of work that I was attempting to promote there,
as I've already indicated, was interdisciplinary.
That is to say,
we needed to get industrial, mechanical, and electrical engineers.
The reward system as it is set up now,
and T's has been part of this,
is one wherein a department head and a faculty member
is credited, literally credited,
with the money he brings to his department.
And if a guy, let's suppose that a program is focused in
some external center, in this center, for example,
we still have this problem.
If I get a half million dollars to do a piece of research,
and I go to mechanical engineering and industrial engineering,
any engineering, simply because the work is attractive,
I get, say, three professors,
one from each one of those departments,
to work with me on the project.
They don't get any credit for that.
And a portion, you know, although they would deserve,
the department would be, would deserve credit
for a portion of that money that I've gotten,
because I got the money based on the capabilities
that exist over there, you see.
But the way the reward structure is set up,
it doesn't address that.
And so that's a real severe problem that, as I say,
exists.
And T's,
about this, and they nod every time I complain.
So what the productivity program,
that when I got some money,
we got some money from the National Science Foundation,
industrial engineering took their little chunk of money
and went back to industrial engineering
and did their little thing,
and they said to hell with these other guys.
And I was just absolutely unable
to bring any kind of an interdisciplinary.
And so there's a real problem there.
But somehow, someway, we have to.
It's not an easy thing.
And Texas A&M and T's is not the only one
that has that problem.
It's a universal problem.
But the productivity.
